NOTEBOOK: A NEW CHANCE FOR NEW MUSIC  
      

   By ANTHONY TOMMASINI   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   The New York Philharmonic's courtship of the conductor Riccardo
Muti has ended, amicably, it appears, but with no success. It had
been no secret that the orchestra was hoping to entice the
perfectionist Italian maestro to take over the music director's
post when Kurt Masur steps down in 2002. But Muti, who has a sure
sense of his own desirability, was playing hard to get. He was
essentially unwilling to scale back his European commitments,
especially as the artistic generalissimo of La Scala.

   Fortunately, the Philharmonic decided that for all Muti's
brilliance and renown, the orchestra needed a full-time music
director. Whatever one may say about the strengths and shortcomings
Masur has brought to the job, no one has ever questioned his
devotion to the New York Philharmonic.

   Now the orchestra must restart its search. And with major music
director posts also up for grabs in Philadelphia and Boston, the
process will not be easy.

   Conductors these days frequently have relationships with several
orchestras at once. Still, that the Philharmonic was interested in
someone, however illustrious, who indicated from the start that he
would treat this important directorship as only one of several
demanding posts says a lot, some of it troubling, about how the
orchestra views the job. What can be learned from what happened?
How might the orchestra adjust its thinking?

   A music director's job has two major components, especially in
an international music center like New York. Obviously, the
Philharmonic must have a brilliantly skilled and musically
top-notch conductor, the kind of probing interpreter who can keep
the players involved, especially in the standard repertory that
audiences want to hear regularly. And if the candidate already has
a well-known name and an extensive discography, as Muti does, that
obviously makes the marketing department happy.

   But a music director in a big city should also be a dynamic
artistic leader, someone who can forge ties with other performing
and educational institutions, someone on close terms with living
composers, an adventurous musician who treats performing new music
not as some weighty obligation but as a bracing activity, a natural
part of what musicians do.

   I have long felt that orchestras, especially in America, place
too much emphasis on the brilliant conductor aspect of the music
director job, when what is crucially needed are vibrant artistic
leaders. Perhaps because America is still nursing a cultural
inferiority complex, orchestras keep going after foreign
heavyweights and older eminences, passing over younger, energetic
Americans who could wake up a cultural community.

   Why not have a younger, idealistic and preferably American
artistic director to run the orchestra day to day, a strong
conductor, of course, but someone who could really galvanize the
institution, conceive stimulating programs, commission worthy
composers and reach out to the larger urban area? Then bring in the
eminences and heavyweights as guests to perform the great repertory
they are steeped in by cultural heritage and long advocacy. Sir
Colin Davis serves this latter role well at the Philharmonic, as no
doubt Masur will and should when his directorship ends.

   Orchestras would be wise to take more chances. Leonard Bernstein
wasn't ``Leonard Bernstein'' when he was appointed to the
Philharmonic post. He was a dynamic, not-yet-40 gamble, which is
probably why for his first season, 1957-58, he was a joint
principal conductor with Dimitri Mitropoulos, and only the next
season was given the job for himself, becoming the first American
music director of a major orchestra in the United States. Obviously
the gamble paid off. Of course, by some accounts, for all the
excitement that Bernstein engendered, the playing of the orchestra
slipped during his tenure. Recordings from the Bernstein era
suggest otherwise. And, unlike every foreign-born conductor in an
American post today, Bernstein did not need an artistic adviser on
staff to tell him what to do.

   Perhaps the Philharmonic feels it got burned by its experience
with Zubin Mehta, who was 42 and hot when he was brought in to give
the orchestra some pizazz after its noble experiment with the
formidably intellectual Pierre Boulez, Bernstein's successor. But
Mehta was not too young and hip; he was too flashy and superficial.

   Masur was recruited in 1991 to bring order to an orchestra that
had grown unruly, to raise standards and to provide rigorous
interpretive insights into the core repertory. He has succeeded on
all counts. Yet the dismayingly conventional programming he has
planned for next year suggests that he is creatively spent.

   He will begin the season with a mini-festival of Mendelssohn, a
composer to whom he has a special claim, having directed the
Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra, which Mendelssohn himself conducted
for 12 years. Though this promises to be distinguished music
making, it would be more welcome if the rest of the season were not
so fixed in the Central European mainstream. There will be lots of
Brahms, Schumann, Dvorak and Mozart. A concert in October,
conducted by Leonard Slatkin, billed as ``honoring the memory of
Leonard Bernstein,'' offers only one work of his, the ``Jeremiah''
Symphony; the bulk of the program is devoted to Mendelssohn's G
minor Piano Concerto and Dvorak's Eighth Symphony.

   To his credit, Masur will acknowledge the 75th birthday of the
important German composer Hans Werne Henze with the American
premiere of his Ninth Symphony and Beethoven's joyous ``Choral
Fantasy'' as a curtain raiser. But for the most part when a new or
recent work is performed (for example, a premiere by Oliver
Knussen), it is sandwiched between crowd pleasers (in that case
Bruch's Violin Concerto and Strauss's ``Also Sprach Zarathustra'').
So don't be scared when you learn that Masur will conduct the New
York premiere of Bright Sheng's ``Red Silk Dance'' for Piano and
Orchestra; Emanuel Ax, the soloist in that work, will also play
Liszt's Second Concerto on a program dominated by Brahms's Second
Symphony. The message indirectly conveyed is that the orchestra is
so afraid of trying something a bit daring that it must be packaged
with reassuring favorites.

   nn

   Muti is a conductor of great stature. I will not soon forget the
three concerts he presented last year at Carnegie Hall with the
Vienna Philharmonic Orchestra. The programs were traditional, the
most recent work being Shostakovich's famous Fifth Symphony. But
the playing was incomparable. Muti's authoritarian approach is
suited, it would seem, to this virtually all-male, tradition-bound
orchestra. Yet to his credit, Muti also got some exciting results
from the New York Philharmonic in recent appearances.

   But what kind of artistic leader would he have made over the
long term? It is hard to imagine what New York cultural or
educational institutions Muti would have formed natural alliances
with. It's equally hard to cite a modern composer with whom Muti
has been associated the way, say, Esa-Pekka Salonen, the excellent
young Finnish-born conductor of the Los Angeles Symphony, has been
linked with Gyorgy Ligeti and Witold Lutoslawski. Salonen's
artistic leadership has not drawn across-the-board praise. Many
West Coast composers complain that in commissioning composers from
his own generation, Salonen has favored Europeans he knows, which
shows the major drawback of not having an American in charge.

   The word is that the Philharmonic musicians strongly wanted
Muti. If true, it's curious. What were they thinking? Perhaps
something along the lines of, ``Maestro Masur has raised the level
of our Beethoven and Bruckner to a new high, and Maestro Muti will
take it higher still.''

   Consider, in comparison, how Michael Tilson Thomas has turned
concert night at the San Francisco Symphony into a cultural must
for young and old alike. His programs are alive with new and recent
works and neglected 20th-century repertory. Yet his audiences get
plenty of Mahler and Brahms. At the opening concert of the
orchestra's ambitious Stravinsky festival last summer, the audience
could have been mistaken for a movie crowd in New York on Saturday
night. Thomas is a great match for San Francisco, with a palpable
connection to American music and strong ties to local composers.

   Robert Spano, 38, a superb technician and orchestra builder,
might have been the kind of exciting, younger, thinking artistic
director I'm calling for. Imagine the Philharmonic with Spano as
its adventurous leader, someone with big ambitions but
self-confident enough to regularly welcome eminent conductors as
guests. Unfortunately, Spano knew that he was probably too young
and too local (as the conductor of the Brooklyn Philharmonic) to
get the Philharmonic job or any of the other major posts about to
be vacated. So he accepted the Atlanta Symphony, a good orchestra,
though perhaps not the best fit: Spano's innovative programming may
be a hard sell for its conservative subscribers.

   Apparently the Philadelphia Orchestra is looking hard at the
41-year-old American conductor David Robertson. Though no
celebrity, he would be an exciting choice. Robertson honed his
conducting skills with complex modern music as an associate of
Pierre Boulez in France. Two years ago he conducted thrilling
performances of daunting works by Elliott Carter and Boulez with
the New Juilliard Ensemble. As music director of the Orchestre
National de Lyon, he has covered the standard repertory thoroughly.
He has also conducted opera impressively, including Janacek's
``Makropoulos Affair'' at the Metropolitan. If the Philharmonic
would adjust its thinking, Robertson could be an inspiring choice.

   Instead, among the names being leaked are two more foreigners
with established reputations: Mariss Jansons, 57, the Latvian-born
music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony and the associate
principal conductor of the St. Petersburg Philharmonic in Russia,
and Christoph Eschenbach, 60, the German chief conductor of the NDR
Symphony in Hamburg. Both are perfectly fine conductors and solid
musicians who would bring indisputable skills to the post. Neither
would seem to be a lively risk-taker who might reach out to
composers and invigorate the city's culture.

   Zarin Mehta, the Philharmonic's new executive director, is said
to be high on both men. My guess is that either would be presented
to the public as a conductor steeped in the European tradition and,
though not as famous or dynamic as Muti, quite distinguished.

   True. But perhaps ``distinction'' has been overvalued in
recruiting music directors to American orchestras. Just by being
appointed to lead the New York Philharmonic, a less-well-known
American would acquire instant distinction. And it would be
refreshing to have someone truly imaginative and exciting, someone
who respects the European tradition but is not cowed by it. It's
something to think about. And now that Muti is out of the picture,
there is time to do just that.
